note.p: Abijah R. Brewer was an executive in the Western Union Telegraph Company in the late nineteenth century. Born in Hunterdon County, New Jersey, on May 3, 1847, Brewer began working at a newspaper office at the age of 15. He studied telegraphy during his free time and became a telegraph operator at the American Telegraph Company in Trenton. In 1875 he was appointed Secretary of the Western Union Telegraph Company and served in that capacity for more than twenty years. Brewer became the Western Union treasurer in 1909 and was subsequently promoted to vice president of the company in 1915. He retired after working more than fifty years for Western Union. Near the end of his life he served a term as mayor of Glen Ridge, New Jersey. Brewer died on November 6, 1919.
(New York Herald, New York City, NY, November 8, 1919)

William Orton was a businessman during the nineteenth century, most famously known as the president of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

Born in Cuba, New York, on June 14, 1826, Orton was trained as a newspaper printer and then went to school to become a teacher. After teaching for several years and working in a book store, he went into the publishing business with various partners, operating Derby, Orton & Company and then Miller & Orton, before working as the managing clerk for J. G. Gregory & Company. In the early 1860s, Orton became involved in public office, serving on New York City’s Common Council, the Collector of Revenue in New York, and then as Commissioner of Internal Revenue in Washington, D.C.

In 1865, Orton left his job in Washington, D.C., to become president of the United States Telegraph Company. A year later, the company merged with Western Union and he was made vice president. Aside from this executive job, Orton studied law and was admitted to the bar (accepted as a professional attorney) in 1867. That same year, the president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Jeptha Wade, resigned, and Orton took his place. He jointly became president of the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, the International Ocean Telegraph Company, and Atlantic and Southern Telegraph Company.

Orton died of apoplexy (a stroke or cerebral hemorrhage) in New York City on April 22, 1878, at the age of 51. He was married to Agnes J. Gillespie and had eight children. Orton is buried in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery in Sleepy Hollow, New York.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: John Marshall Stone served as governor of Mississippi two separate times, from 1876 to 1882 and from 1890 to 1896.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, on March 29, 1876, Stone grew up mostly in poverty but worked for his education and eventually became a school teacher. He moved to Mississippi in the mid-1850s and found work as a railroad station agent at Iuka, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Stone joined the Confederate army. He was placed in command of Company K of the 2nd Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Proving capable in battle during campaigns in Virginia, he was promoted in 1862 to colonel of the regiment and received high praise from his superiors during the rest of the war. Stone led his regiment until near the end of the war, when he was captured in North Carolina and sent to Ohio as a prisoner.

Upon his release after the Civil War, Stone returned to Mississippi and resumed his work with the Mississippi and Ohio Railroad at Iuka. He married Mary G. Coman in 1872 and had two children, both of whom died before adulthood. Stone and his wife also adopted and raised three of his nephews.

He entered politics in 1869, winning election to the Mississippi state senate as a Democrat. In 1873 and 1874, Democrats in Mississippi gained majority power following campaigns of voter intimidation and violence against African Americans and Republicans. Stone worked his way to president pro tempore of the Senate during this period. In 1876, the Democrat majority in the state legislature carried out an impeachment campaign against top Republican officials, including Governor Adelbert Ames and Lieutenant Governor Alexander K. Davis. When Davis was impeached and Ames was forced to resign to avoid a costly lawsuit against politically-driven impeachment charges, Stone became next in line for governor. He was sworn into office in March 1876.

Stone served as acting-governor for a year and a half and then won the gubernatorial election in 1877, running as the sole candidate. He lost reelection in 1881 to Robert Lowry, but retained his interest in the governor’s office and ran again—and won—in 1889. Mississippi adopted a new constitution in 1890, which in part extended Stone’s gubernatorial term until 1896 to aid the transition of new policies. The new constitution prohibited successive gubernatorial terms. Thus, Stone could not run for immediate reelection. Upon leaving office, he received an appointment as president of the Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College (now Mississippi State University) in Starkville. He died in 1900 and is buried at Oak Grove Cemetery in Iuka, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Dan Sansing, “John Marshall Stone: Thirty-first and Thirty-third Governor of Mississippi: 1876-1882; 1890–1896,” Mississippi History Now)

note.p: Alexander K. Davis was a representative in the Mississippi legislature and served as the state’s lieutenant governor from 1874 to 1876, during Reconstruction. He was the first African American lieutenant governor of Mississippi.

Little was recorded of Davis’ past. His date and place of birth are not known. During testimony before Congress in 1871 he explained that he moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, from Tennessee in 1869, and said he had been admitted to the bar (a reference that he had been accepted as a practicing attorney in a city or county), but did not specify in which state. He won a seat in Mississippi’s House of Representatives shortly after coming to Mississippi and became a leading figure in the state’s Republican Party circles. In 1873, Radical Republicans backed by a majority of African American voters in Mississippi, won a series of state elections. Davis was one of three African Americans elected to statewide office that year, winning the lieutenant governor seat. (The other Black figures to win statewide election were James Hill as secretary of state and T. W. Cardozo as state superintendent of education.) The following year, white conservatives carried out a campaign of intimidation and violence to suppress Republican and African American voting and put Democrats into political power. The effort worked and by 1875, Democrats held a majority of state legislative seats. Emboldened by their political power, Democrats tried to rid Republicans from many state positions. They specifically targeted Davis and northern-born and Radical Republican Governor Adelbert Ames, accusing both men of improprieties in office. Davis was charged with illegal granting of pardons. Despite his effort to fight the trumped-up charges, Mississippi Democrats impeached Davis in March 1876. Knowing that the conviction would result in him being removed from office, Davis resigned. Governor Ames, also facing politically-driven impeachment proceedings that would require extensive time and financial resources to fight, resigned as well. Following his resignation, Davis abandoned politics. He moved to Canton, Mississippi and worked as a pastor. He died on November 21, 1884.
(Wikipedia; Dernoral Davis, "Alexander K. Davis," Mississippi Encyclopedia; Clyde Tucker, “Alexander K. Davis (?-1884),” Black Past)

When Colfax County (now Clay County) was established on May 11, 1871, West Point became its county seat and remains so today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 956; Britannica)

gloss.p: Established in 1876, J. S. Hamilton & Company (also known as Hamilton & Hebron and Hoskins & Hamilton) was a business operated by Jones S. Hamilton, John L. Hebron, James A. Hoskins, and William H. Gibbs that privatized the penitentiary system in Mississippi by leasing prisoners from the state. The company and its convict leasing business model was championed by Democratic politicians in Mississippi as they took majority rule over Republicans near the end of Reconstruction. Rather than pay for badly needed repairs in the state prison system, the Mississippi government leased its entire prison population to J. S. Hamilton & Co., which in turn subleased the convicts to labor projects and plantation owners. The company also used prisoners for manufacturing several consumer products, such as wagons, plows, tables, picture frames, leather boots, and shoes, all sold directly by J.S. Hamilton & Co, and it offered contracting for railroads, including the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad, and other public improvements.

Democratic politicians celebrated the convict leasing program, claiming that it brought money to the state treasury, and they recommended the privatization and leasing of the penitentiary system to prison officials in other states. (Indeed, Alabama authorized convict leasing from 1876 until 1928, reporting in 1898 that the income from leased convict labor accounted for 73% of the state’s revenue that year.) The Mississippi legislature leased the penitentiary to J. S. Hamilton & Co. through at least 1883. In 1890, Mississippi prohibited the leasing of convict labor, and J. S. Hamilton & Co. must have closed then if not in the years prior.

(The American Citizen, June 17, 1876; The Comet, February 15, 1879; The Semi-Weekly Leader, May 10, 1883; The Winston County Journal, February 15, 1929; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, July 12, 1876, November 15, 1876, and January 2, 1878; Commonwealth of Pennsylvania: Legislative Documents Comprising the Department and Other Reports, Made to the Senate and House of Representatives of Pennsylvania During the Session of 1878, Vol. III, 255; The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, June 11, 1887; W. David Ball, “Why State Prisons?” Yale Law & Policy Review, Rev. 75 [2014], 96)Located in Jackson, Mississippi, Jones S. Hamilton & Co. (also known as Hoskins & Hamilton) was a business owned and operated by Jones S. Hamilton, James A. Hoskins, and William H. Gibbs and was in operation at least from 1876 to 1883. multi-faceted company involved in convict leasing, railroad contracting, and manufacturing. In June 1876, it was awarded the Mississippi Board of Penetentiary's contract for leasing convict labor, and this cheap labor was crucial to its success. The company offered contracting for railroad work, including the Gulf & Ship Island railroad, and other public improvements and was a manufacturer of wagons, agricultural equipment, and leather. Manufacturing often took place within the penetentiary walls. In 1890, Mississippi prohibited the leasing of convict labor, and J. S. Hamilton & Co. must have closed then if not in the years prior.
(The American Citizen, June 17, 1876; The Clarion-Ledger, January 2, 1878; The Comet, February 15, 1879; The Semi-Weekly Leader, May 10, 1883; The Winston County Journal, February 15, 1929)

In the U.S., convict leasing began as early as 1823 in New York and 1844 in Louisiana. Convict leasing brokers were individuals or private companies who would often lease all of the state's convicts before subleasing them to others individuals at increased rates, generally for agricultural labor.

After the Civil War, although the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of Black people, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies and to replace enslaved labor. In certain cases, the lessee had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased convict.

Peaking around 1880, this system was highly lucrative for the states and convict leasing brokers. Prison populations increased across the South, directly reflecting demands. And through the South's Black Codes, which severely limited the rights of formerly enslaved people, Black men and women could be arrested for a number of petty crimes. Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality ensured that convict labor leasing fell most heavily on Black men, although there were some white men and Black women.

Working conditions were harsh and exploitative, with convicts receiving brutal punishments and little shelter, food, or medical care. Companies and private individuals did also lease enslaved workers during the antebellum era, but enslavers expected these workers to be "returned alive and in good working condition." (Sturkey, Hattiesburg) These protections did not extend to convict laborers, and the resulting death tolls were staggering.

Negative publicity for the system led convict labor leasing to be phased out over the course of the early-twentieth-century, with Alabama being the last state to officially end it in 1928. However, individual counties across the South, continued it for many years, and the states themselves often continued using convict labor for state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of Black men while perpetuating anti-Black racism. This also laid the foundations of the modern prison system.
(Wikipedia; Mississippi Encyclopedia; Library of Congress)

catDesc.term: Telegraph Companies--The Western Union Telegraph Company (Rochester, N.Y.)

gloss.p: Headquartered in Rochester, New York, the Western Union Telegraph Company was a telegraph company established in 1851. Before the Civil War, the telegraph was a growing technology, but Western Union brought it to the national stage, especially upon the completion of the transcontinental line in 1861. Western Union Telegraph Company provided near-instantaneous communication between the Union government and its far-reaching troops, allowing for faster troop movement, supply coordination, and battlefield updates. Western Union also facilitated communication between families, boosting morale and providing vital wartime news. However, the war fractured the network as Confederate and Union forces targeted telegraph lines, disrupting communication and necessitating constant repairs. The South relied on a separate system, hindering Confederate coordination and leaving them at an informational disadvantage. During Reconstruction, Western Union facilitated communication between the federal government and freed people, by relaying news of political and social developments, and Black communities seized the technology to organize their efforts in the fight for civil rights. However, Western Union's power faced criticism for its role in suppressing dissent and reinforcing control during Reconstruction. (Wikipedia; Western Union; National Archives; Smithsonian)In 1851, the Western Union telegraph company was founded in Rochester, NY under the name the New York and Mississippi Valley Printing Telegraph Company. In 1856, the company merged with the Erie and Michigan Telegraph Company and was renamed the Western Union Telegraph Company. An innovator in technology, by October 1861, it completed the first transcontinental telegraph by sending a message from the west coast to President Abraham Lincoln on the east coast. This accomplishment set the stage for the company to dominate the telegraph industry in the United States after the Civil War. In 1871, it also pioneered wire money transfer, which increasingly became the focus of the company throughout the 1980s and 1990s. The Western Union company continues today as a strictly money-transferring industry, having abandoned its communications operations in 2006. (Wikipedia)

When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).

Like many slaveholding states of the former Confederacy, Mississippi operated a convict leasing system between the 1860s–1900s. Under convict leasing systems, states leased imprisoned people to perform unfree labor for companies and individuals in exchange for a fee. State and county laws (such as "Pig Laws" and vagrancy laws) and racially selective prosecutions funneled large, overrepresented populations of African Americans into their prison institutions. Therefore, Mississippi's convict leasing system replaced the state's former system of race-based chattel slavery and laborers encountered harsh conditions, violent punishments, and high death tolls. Public outcry over these conditions, especially following the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company's convict leasing practices, forced Mississippi to abolish its convict leasing program in 1890, becoming the first state to do so. County governments, however, continued to operate convict leasing arrangements using chain gangs until the 1900s. In 1904 Mississippi opened Parchman Prison on a cotton plantation in the Mississippi Delta and consolidated much of its convict labor there. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)
